Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal proposes to commercialize the technology, Light Modulated Acoustic Devices (LMAD) to translate basic research on photonic materials from the laboratory to the market place. Controlling sound actively using light is challenging and is considered to be one of the holy grail of acoustics technology due to the fundamental differences in the nature of the acoustic and electromagnetic waves. The PI and his team propose to commercialize the technology to photo-actively control phononic properties remotely using the novel dielectric properties of nanoparticles embedded in phononic crystals. Since phononics deals with vibrations, acoustic or otherwise, potential applications range from active, non-contact vibration dampening for vehicles and devices, to smart, high resolution ultrasound technology, to environmental technologies to actively reduce noise pollution. LMADs are part of the subcategory of technology of photonics, phononics.

Greater dynamic flexibility in existing focused-sound technologies will be achieved via this technology. Active selective-filtering element for vibration dampening can be used to filter out selected unwanted vibration modes. Typical customers would consist of manufacturers of ultrasonic equipment for either hyperthermic biomedical, imaging, or structural characterization applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ICorps team on Light Modulated Acoustic Device was formed to explore the commercialization of the technology developed by the Entrepreneurial lead who was a graduate student in the PI's laboratory at the University of North Texas. The team was mentored by the Technology transfer officer at the University of North Texas. Members of the team participated in the October 2013 Cohort. A business model canvas pertaining to the added benefits of the innovation to the medical diagnostic community was constructed. Over 100 interviews were performed with end users, payers, influencers, suppliers, distributors, and other key personnel in the ultrasound and general medical diagnostic ecosystem. Discussions with experts on the technical side of ultrasonic diagnostic imaging were queried to assess the technical viability of the tunable solid state acoustic lens for HD diagnostic imaging systems. Technical response to the technology was enthusiastic, and interviews with persons in this realm confirmed the gap in technology between phased array transducers and solid state lens. The TUL HD Imaging device would represent a positive step in reducing the diagnostic imaging component cost and bridging the limitations between transducer array and solid state lens technologies.

iCorps interviews revealed amongst sonographers that incorporating their practical feedback was the most important way to build rapport since they are the primary users of the technology. Radiologists, who heavily influence decisions, focused primarily of the practical effectiveness of the technology versus other modalities. So, demonstrating the practical capabilities of the technology in medical journals and in-person demonstrations would have the strongest effects. The persons who make the ‘buy’ decisions are most strongly influenced by hospital directors who are strongly influenced by their radiologists and the equipment costs. For the directors, direct person to person interaction will be the route used so that new Imaging technology developed by the team is recognized by a significant portion of the ecosystem.

The product of the project are as follows:

Patent Inssued:  Tunable polymer-based sonic structures;  US 20140060960 A1;

Inventors - Ezekiel Walker, Tong Cai and Arup Neogi 

The rights to the patent are owned by the University of North Texas and the inventors on the patent will be participants on this award. 

The  EL for the iCorps Teams grant, Dr. Ezekiel (Zeke) Walker, has graduated from University of North Texas with a Ph.D physics, but has also jointly pursued an M.B.A. He has founded the company Echonovus Inc. with the sole purpose of bringing the tunable ultrasonic (TUL) high definition imaging technology to the marketplace. He will function as a CEO/COO  in the initial stages, implementing the brand-building strategy mentioned in the prior paragraph. The TUL technology was born from his Ph.D work, and he also is an author to the two patents. Echonovus Inc. will collaborate with Dr. Arup Neogi to develop the TUL technology and bring it out of the lab to the marketplace.




Last Modified: 11/03/2015
Modified by: Arup Neogi
